ASIA-PAC SERVICE IS NOW LIVE FOR TODAY'S SESSION
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
8th January 2020

GEOPOLITICS

Unconfirmed reports suggest alarm sirens can be heard at the US Consulate in Erbil, Iraq, according to Egyptian Al-Ghad TV. However, some suggest the sirens heard at the US Consulate are apparently tests, according to Elint News citing an Al-Mayadeen Correspondent (Twitter)

US forces and air-defence missile batteries were reportedly placed on high alert across the Middle-East on Monday night, due to intelligence which was mounting indicating the threat of an imminent attack against US targets., CNN citing US Officials. (CNN)

US President Trump said he would like to withdraw US troops from Iraq at some point; would only consider Iraq sanctions if the US is not treated with respect. (Newswires)

US Defense Secretary Esper said US is open to meeting with Iran. US Defense Secretary Esper says US wants the Iran situation deescalated and does not want war, but is ready to finish one, according to CNN interview. US Secretary of State Pompeo states he is confident that in the event Iran makes another bad choice, he is confident that US President Trump will respond as he did last week. (Newswires)

US President Trump said he spoke to Saudi Defense Minister on trade, military, oil prices, security, and stability in the Middle East. (Newswires)

EU's Minister for Foreign Affairs Borrell has rejected plans from Turkey to send military personal to Libya. (Newswires)

Iran has reportedly moved its military equipment to protect it from potential US strikes/attacks. (Al-Jazeera)

Iran IRGC spokesperson says Soleimani funeral will be moved to another day, will not be finished today, on account of the stampede. (Twitter)

 

ASIA-PAC

China Global Times Editor notes based on what he knows China is actively preparing for a signing of the phase one trade deal with the US. (Twitter)

"There are still many things that could go wrong,” warns China's Global Times on the 15th January Phase One deal signing. Similarly, China's vice chairman of the China Society for WTO said there are still some areas where China and the US "need to work out more details, e.g., both appear divided over the specific quantity of China's purchases of US products". (Newswires)

China financial stability committee says it will take steps to ease the funding burden of medium and small enterprises; will use multiple monpol tools; will boost capital and SMEs to enhance lending. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

BoE Governor Carney says despite concerns on a potential downturn, he is optimistic on the post Brexit future, he also forecasts a liquidity trap threat undermining the effort on a fight against a recession by the central bank; FT reports. The governor also recommends the government to use fiscal tools, like tax cuts or an increase to public spending when fighting a downturn. States he is not leaving upcoming governor Bailey without any tools in the arsenal, noting the central bank could still reduce rates to close to 0% from the current 0.75%, and could "supplement monetary policy with macroprudential tools". (FT)

PSOE leader Sanchez has been voted in as PM in investiture vote, as expected; 167-165, with 18 abstentions. (Newswires)

DATA RECAP

-        EU HICP Flash YY (Dec) 1.3% vs. Exp. 1.3% (Prev. 1.0%) (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

US sources said the Trump administration is mulling sanctions against some Venezuelan lawmakers, names Luis Parra. (Newswires)

US Private Inventory Crude Stocks (3rd Jan) -5.9mln (exp. -3.6mln, prev. -7.8mln) (Newswires)

 

US 

DATA RECAP

-        US ISM N-Mfg PMI (Dec) 55.0 vs. Exp. 54.5 (Prev. 53.9) (Newswires) US ISM N-Mfg Employment Idx (Dec) 55.2 (Prev. 55.5) US ISM N-Mfg New Orders Idx (Dec) 54.9 (Prev. 57.1)

-        US Durable Goods, R MM (Nov) -2.1% (Prev. -2.0%) (Newswires)

-        US Factory Orders MM (Nov) -0.7% vs. Exp. -0.8% (Prev. 0.3%, Rev. 0.2%)

 

MARKET RECAP

* CLOSING LEVELS: SPX -0.3% at 3237; NDX unchanged at 8846; DJIA -0.4% at 28,584. * STOCK SPECIFICS: Apache (APA) added more than 25% to its market cap upon a new oil discovery, alongside Total (TOT, FP FP) offshore of Suriname. Micron (MU) surged on an upgrade at Cowen on improving DRAM fundamentals; Western Digital (WDC) was also supported by an upgrade by the same analyst, further supporting the wide semiconductor sector (SOX). Microchip Technology (MCHP) was another outperformer after it signalled a bottoming out of the cycle in December and raised its guidance. Tesla (TSLA) firmed on the back of reports it was to begin production of its Model Y SUVs at its new Shanghai plant, with CEO Musk optimistic about its demand. Boeing (BA) was supported by chatter of Warren Buffet’s Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.B) taking an interest, paring back earlier losses from an Underperform initiation at Longbow. Merck (MRK) and Chevron (CVX) traded at the bottom of the Dow, with the former missing endpoints on a Phase 3 Keytruda study and the latter suffering from a downgrade at BofA; note Exxon (XOM) and the wider energy sector (XLE) underperformed amid lower crude prices on a slight pare-back of the geopolitical risk premium. Goldman Sachs (GS) traded higher on reports in the WSJ it would be revamping its corporate accounting structure to increase transparency, also that its executives believe the stock is worth USD 400. Kellogg (K) and Square (SQ) both benefitted from upgrades at Credit Suisse and BofA, respectively. Accenture (ACN) suffered after being downgraded at both MoffettNathanson and BofA. JPMorgan (JPM) took a hit on a downgrade at UBS.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (H20) SETTLED 3 TICKS LOWER AT 129-05. The T-Note edged slightly lower in what was a lacklustre day regarding market activity; the curve was slightly steeper, 30-year yield +3bps and 2-year yield unchanged. The recent geopolitical induced risk-off move has taken a bit of a breather, with both Treasuries and oil prices coming off their recent highs. Some participants are likely cautious ahead of the supply slate this week, with new year’s corporate issuance ramping up alongside the Treasury auctions. One analyst notes that steepeners are likely being entered ahead of the 10- and 30-year auctions in the next few days, indicative of a concession effort ahead of Friday’s NFP report to “seamlessly underwrite the auctions.”

subject: Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 7th January 2020: Risk off moves pauses in anticipation of next Middle East escalation
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities flat/lower, Treasuries flat, Dollar up, Crude down
  • REAR VIEW: Iran proposes 13 “scenarios” for retaliation; US non-manufacturing ISM beats and trade deficit narrows; chatter of BA receiving interest from Warren Buffet.
  • COMING UP: Data & Events: US ADP National Employment (Dec) and Consumer Credit (Nov); EIA weekly energy inventories; German Industrial Orders (Nov); Riksbank Minutes (Dec); US 10-year auction. Speakers: EU Commission President von der Leyen; Fed’s Brainard (voter, neutral); ECB’s de Guindos (dovish). Earnings: WBA, STZ & LEN.

US MARKET WRAP 7th January 2020: Risk off moves pauses in anticipation of next Middle East escalation

* IRAN: The secretary of the Supreme National Security Council said Iran was assessing 13 scenarios for retaliation against the US, according to Fars, adding that the weakest option will turn into a 'historic nightmare' for the Americans. It follows a chain of punchy rhetoric; the key for traders is what the exact nature of the retaliation will be, and whether that disrupts oil supply in the Middle East; there seems to be a consensus developing that Iran will either opt to attack US (and its allies) military assets in the Middle East via proxies, while attacks to oil infrastructure cannot be ruled out (similar to the attacks on Saudi facilities in September); there are also suggestions that Iran might use its sophisticated cyber army against US interests. The US would view any of these actions as a serious escalation, and President Trump has pledged to aggressively respond. In anticipation of such attacks, CNN reported citing US officials that US forces and air-defence missile batteries were reportedly placed on high alert across the Middle East on Monday night, due to intelligence which was mounting indicating the threat of an imminent attack against US targets. Meanwhile, one remark which has not received much coverage was a senior Iranian official has stating that the nation was prepared to "come back to full compliance in the Nuclear deal"; the terms of such a return were not specified, however, Iran has historically demanded sanctions relief as a pre-requisite for such action.

* US NON-MANUFACTURING ISM (DEC): The December non-manufacturing ISM report was solid, and analysts said it should dispel the notion that the slowdown in manufacturing surveys heralds weakness in the wider economy. The headline rose 1.1 points in the month, to 55.0, rising above expectations of 54.5. The business activity sub-index rose by a hefty 5.6 points to 57.2 – Wells Fargo said that it serves as the latest indication that activity in the service sector continues to hold up as manufacturing activity has floundered, and notes that other purchasing manager indices - Markit and regional Fed – were consistent with the December gain in the ISM non-manufacturing index, confirming stabilisation within the sector. Ahead of this week’s employment situation report, the employment sub-index fell a touch to 55.2 from 55.5, though WFC still thinks it is a solid read. Meanwhile, the forward-looking new orders sub-index declined by 2.2 points, though still remain comfortably in expansion territory, suggesting growth in the sector, WFC writes.

* US-CHINA: The Chinese Vice Agricultural Minister said China will not increase annual grain import quotas to accommodate higher US farm purchases, Caixin reported, drawing scepticism on the USD 40bln-50bln agricultural figure the US has been touting; a separate Chinese official, who is not part of the primary trade team, said later that there is still areas of disagreement on the purchases figure and the China Global Times warned there is still things that could go wrong. Participants are anxious for a publication of the agreement prior to its signing to see how detailed it is, with the logic being, the thinner it is on details and specifics, such as a hard agricultural purchases figure, the less substantial the agreement is and the greater pressure on the global growth outlook. However, the Global Times also reported that the Phase One deal is on track and could be signed in the near future, citing sources, although note the lack of a specific date; US President Trump and other US officials have noted January 15th as the signing date, which is scheduled to take place in Washington.

* US INTERNATIONAL TRADE BALANCE (NOV): The trade deficit narrowed more than expected, to USD 43.1bln from USD 46.9bln, underpinned by a decline in imports. The implication is that net trade may be a significant contributor to Q4 GDP growth. Import weakness might be explained by temporary factors, Capital Economics says. One spot that received much attention was the fact that the US has now run a trade surplus in petroleum products for three straight months, underlining how much more insulated the economy is to a potential spike in crude prices, CapEco writes.

* US FACTORY ORDERS (NOV): Factory orders in November declined by 0.7% M/M (consensus -0.8% M/M), and the prior month’s print was revised down 0.1%. The core, ex-transport measure rose 0.3% M/M.

* CHINA FX RESERVES: Data showed FX reserves rising in December to USD 3.108trln (from USD 3.096trln), slightly short of the expected USD 3.11trln. The Street's expectation of a stronger rise was premised on dollar weakness in the period. Pantheon Macroeconomics said it is unlikely that the authorities were selling reserves with any intent to hold the currency back from appreciation. "They have been very careful not to derail the fragile trade talks with the US, supporting the currency through its weak times, though that doesn’t always show up in FX reserves,"  and the optimism around the deal last month kept the RMB appreciating, giving the authorities some breathing space. "These data suggest that capital outflows edged up minimally in December, assuming that the trade surplus was little changed, we reckon the Phase One deal should make it over the line as planned this month, while signs of green shoots in the economy also should support the currency, though we still see only stabilisation in the economy at large and think the recovery is on shaky legs, for now," Pantheon writes, adding that, at the same time, "progress on a comprehensive deal seems unlikely, so this could be as good as it gets for the RMB from that perspective."

* EUROZONE HICP (DEC): Eurozone consumer prices rose in line with expectations, flash December data showed, rising 1.3% Y/Y from 1.0%, while the core measure held at 1.3% Y/Y. ING’s analysts said that, despite the strong increase, it is premature for hawks to get excited, and this is not an environment in which core inflation pressures are increasing: “Depending on oil price developments, which are likely to be volatile as Middle East tensions have spiked recently, it is expected that inflation could trend somewhat higher than the 1% range for the coming months,” ING writes, “but the real story though is in core inflation, which has been at 1.3% for two months in a row now.” ING notes this is higher than expected and might encourage hawks at the ECB to seek some clawback of the monetary stimulus provided in the second half of last year. Nevertheless, ING says that “predictions for a sustained rise in core inflation still seem premature, as wage pressures have been moderating recently thanks to the sluggish and uncertain economic environment. The same holds for selling price expectations which have been trending down, indicating that more modest price growth is in the making in the months ahead.” The bank adds that, while the higher core inflation reading will be on the ECB's radar, continued sluggish growth and subsiding wage pressures make a quick rise to the 1.5-2% range an upside risk scenario, rather than a base case,” and adds that, without material improvement in business confidence and the growth outlook, continued modest price growth seems the most likely scenario for the moment.

* CANADA TRADE (NOV): The deficit narrowed to USD 1.1bln, with imports slipping 2.4% M/M, while exports fell 1.4% M/M. RBC notes that, while transitory factors may be in play, recent Canadian data has nevertheless been weak. "The data comes on the heels of a soft run of economic numbers for October - culminating in a 0.1% decline in GDP in that month - and follows a very soft November labour market report," RBC writes, "the external trade backdrop arguably still has room to improve given some thawing in tensions between the US and China." However, RBC argues that softer domestic data reports will keep attention focused on the next batch of Canadian reports, not the least of which will be the next round of employment numbers for December later this week.

* AUSTRALIA BUSH FIRES: The Aussie is under pressure, as local banks begin cutting their views of Q1 GDP with the recent wildfires likely to drag on growth. While the outlook is becoming more uncertain, desks are of the view that, at the minimum, the initial impact will be higher inflation and lower growth; while there are expectations that fiscal authorities will loosen the strings (it has pledged AUD 1bln over a two-year horizon), the amounts are not large enough to offset the full effect. The onus then moves on to the RBA, which has stated that if it downgrades the outlook, it would also lower the Cash Rate in response, meaning RBA easing has become more likely.

* BREXIT: MPs returned from recess on Tuesday and began debating the Brexit Withdrawal Bill in a committee stage, which passed as expected; it is also expected to pass through the UK's Upper House without any drama. On Wednesday, new EU Commission President Von der Leyen will be in London to meet UK PM Johnson (EU Brexit negotiator Barnier will join in too), and she will also speak at the LSE. The UK is likely to push for accelerated negotiations in order to avoid any cliff-edge scenarios (the UK must by July decide on whether it will extend the transition period beyond the end-2020 timeline). The sides are also likely to discuss the situation in the Middle East.

* SPAIN POLITICS: PSOE Leader Sanchez today was voted in by parliament as PM to lead a minority coalition government comprised of the PSOE socialists and the leftist Podemos party. The vote was close at 167-165, with 18 abstentions, but was expected given that Sanchez last week secured commitment of Catalan parties to abstain, lowering the bar for approval given a simple majority was needed (vs an absolute majority, which PSOE failed at on Sunday). The party has taken aim at big banks threatening higher taxes which resulted in downside for Spanish banks on Tuesday. All is not clear however, as in return for the Catalan parties’ abstentions, Sanchez has agreed to open formal talks on the future of Catalonia, which will be put to a citizen’s vote. Oxford Economics highlights that governing will be very challenging given the extremely narrow margins; thus it will require support from the smaller parties, and therefore OxEco believes it is highly unlikely the coalition will last for its four-year term. Following the result, analysts at Oxford Economics raised its deficit forecast, despite the government’s commitment to deficit targets, as fiscal numbers are coming in weaker than expected.

* WTI (G0) SETTLED USD 0.57 LOWER AT USD 62.70/BBL; BRENT (H0) SETTLED USD 0.64 LOWER AT USD 68.27/BBL. Oil prices came off their recent highs on Tuesday amid a slight reduction in the geopolitical risk premium as participants digest the recent Middle East tensions. Many participants draw attention to the swift reversal of prices in the wake of the Saudi oil facilities attacks in September 2019, although Citigroup’s analysts note Iran’s open call for a proportional counterattack as an indication that the current tensions remain elevated. Some participants may be profit taking too ahead of the energy inventories, where the API reports Tuesday evening ahead of the official EIA release on Wednesday. Current expectations (bbls) see crude stocks -3.6mln, distillates +3.9mln, gasoline +2.7mln and Genscape forecast Cushing stocks -0.66mln.

* CLOSING LEVELS: SPX -0.3% at 3237; NDX unchanged at 8846; DJIA -0.4% at 28,584.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Apache (APA) added more than 25% to its market cap upon a new oil discovery, alongside Total (TOT, FP FP) offshore of Suriname. Micron (MU) surged on an upgrade at Cowen on improving DRAM fundamentals; Western Digital (WDC) was also supported by an upgrade by the same analyst, further supporting the wide semiconductor sector (SOX). Microchip Technology (MCHP) was another outperformer after it signalled a bottoming out of the cycle in December and raised its guidance. Tesla (TSLA) firmed on the back of reports it was to begin production of its Model Y SUVs at its new Shanghai plant, with CEO Musk optimistic about its demand. Boeing (BA) was supported by chatter of Warren Buffet’s Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.B) taking an interest, paring back earlier losses from an Underperform initiation at Longbow. Merck (MRK) and Chevron (CVX) traded at the bottom of the Dow, with the former missing endpoints on a Phase 3 Keytruda study and the latter suffering from a downgrade at BofA; note Exxon (XOM) and the wider energy sector (XLE) underperformed amid lower crude prices on a slight pare-back of the geopolitical risk premium. Goldman Sachs (GS) traded higher on reports in the WSJ it would be revamping its corporate accounting structure to increase transparency, also that its executives believe the stock is worth USD 400. Kellogg (K) and Square (SQ) both benefitted from upgrades at Credit Suisse and BofA, respectively. Accenture (ACN) suffered after being downgraded at both MoffettNathanson and BofA. JPMorgan (JPM) took a hit on a downgrade at UBS.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (H20) SETTLED 3 TICKS LOWER AT 129-05. The T-Note edged slightly lower in what was a lacklustre day regarding market activity; the curve was slightly steeper, 30-year yield +3bps and 2-year yield unchanged. The recent geopolitical induced risk-off move has taken a bit of a breather, with both Treasuries and oil prices coming off their recent highs. Some participants are likely cautious ahead of the supply slate this week, with new year’s corporate issuance ramping up alongside the Treasury auctions. One analyst notes that steepeners are likely being entered ahead of the 10- and 30-year auctions in the next few days, indicative of a concession effort ahead of Friday’s NFP report to “seamlessly underwrite the auctions.”

* 3-YEAR AUCTION: US 3-year supply was mediocre, tailing by 0.3bps, with cover a touch beneath recent averages, and the auction did see some slight slippage in wake of the sale. IFR noted that dealers and specs sold the post auction trade with an eye on the duration heavy supply ahead. Desks also note that the corporate supply slate is also heavy this week, providing some competition to Treasuries. 

* 10-YEAR AUCTION PREVIEW: SocGen's analysts say the 10-year sector has slight set up for the upcoming auction from a relative-value perspective, and the bank feels it looks cheap in both asset swap and on the fly versus 5s and 30s. On an outright basis, the sector appears somewhat rich compared to the last auction cycle, but still appears cheaps on 2s10s given that the curve has steepened since the last auction. SocGen observes that the current 10 trades special in repo, which indicates strong demand for the issue, while the low dealer holdings in the 7-10 year sector might also be a positive. "We expect fear of escalating geopolitical risks to put a cap on bond yields in the near term, thereby increasing demand among investors for safe assets like Treasuries," SocGen says, adding "we are positive on this auction."

* FX: USD was higher, bid in the morning as US players arrived ahead of trade data and ISM Non-Manufacturing PMI. The Dollar Index (DXY) crossed the key 97.0 figure just prior to the trade data which saw the narrowest deficit since summer of 2017, and extended gains and was boosted following the stronger PMI data. CAD losses accelerated in today’s session, with USDCAD crossing over the psychological 1.30 figure to highs of 1.3029, before paring slightly. The Loonie weakness coincides with a retracement of oil prices which have now pared roughly half of the geopolitical drive move price spike as a chance of extreme escalation seems to have dissipated slightly for now. RUB also trading on similar themes to CAD given Russia’s oil export dominated economy. AUD underperforms as local banks cut Q1 GDP estimates due the recent wildfires, which has increased the probability of a February rate cut from the RBA to around 40% according to OIS. Havens traded somewhat defensive, though XAU continued its rally to highs of 1572, from lows of 1555 overnight. Analysts at Nomura highlight that CTAs appear to have shifted towards rebuilding their gold positions and say that USDJPY gains appear to have hit a ceiling for now. It is also worth highlighting analysts have been keeping an eye on real yields, which have ticked up on Tuesday. EUR traded weaker against the buck amid broad dollar strength which broke a few EURUSD technical levels after falling from highs just shy of 1.12 breaching 1.1150 and the 200dma at 1.1142 briefly, before paring regaining ground and residing around the key technical level heading into Asia trade. GBP lower today, with focus shifting to PM’s meeting with EU Commission president Von Der Leyen on Wednesday.

content:
THIS WEEK’S TREASURY SUPPLY: The US Treasury will this week auction anew 3-year note (USD 38bln, Tuesday), a 10-year re-opening (USD 24bln, Wednesday) and a 30-year re-opening (USD 16bln, Thursday). UBS says there will be a total of USD 26bln of cash flows (ex SOMA) this week, including USD 24bln of redemptions and USD 2bln of coupons; over the next four weeks, gross supply will total USD 191bln, the bank notes. 

3-YEAR PREVIEW: SocGen's analysts say the upcoming auction has not got clear set-up from a relative value perspective, noting that it trades fair in asset swap and on the fly versus 2s and 5s. "The sector looks rich on an outright basis versus the last two auctions, as the current 3y when-issued yield is trading below the stop-yield of previous two auctions," SocGen writes, "however, currently Treasury yields are in the middle of their recent range, and given the risk of rising geopolitical tensions, we expect buyers of Treasuries to materialise." The bank notes that dealer holdings are relatively low in the front-end of the curve, which may support demand at the auction. The bank says it is positive on the auction, but suggests that the ISM services PMI, which is released three hours ahead of the auction, may play a role; any upside surprise may see the sector cheapen, adding to the allure of the issue, the bank writes.

Daily FX Wrap: troubling Tuesday for the non-US Dollars, but Buck content
content:
AUD/NZD/CAD/DXY

Aussie losses have been piling up over the course of the session, and especially once a few key levels/supports gave way, like 0.6900 and 0.6897 (200 DMA) against the Greenback and 1.0367 (18 December low) vs the Kiwi, to leave Aud/Usd probing below the 50 DMA (0.6870) and Aud/Nzd hovering just above 1.0350 after a dip to 1.0340. The catalyst or rather bearish combination of factors emanate from the ongoing bushfires and extend to renewed RBA easing expectations on the premise that the economic fallout will be too pronounced for the CB and Government to address without further monetary and fiscal action. Indeed, data overnight highlighted the damage beyond the obvious physical and environmental costs as job ads tumbled. Elsewhere, Nzd/Usd also declined, albeit a bit less aggressively through 0.6650 towards 0.6625 in sympathy, and continued to largely ignore GDT auction results, while the Loonie lost power as crude prices recoiled and Usd/Cad breached its 2019 close (1.2987) on the way through 1.3000 towards 1.3030. Note also, following pretty similar Canadian and US trade data in terms of actual deficits vs consensus the contrast between non-manufacturing ISM and Ivey PMIs could not have been more glaring as the former beat expectations handsomely vs significantly weaker SA and NSA prints. Hence, the US Dollar proffered not just on the back of others, but in its own right, with the index trying to maintain recovery gains/momentum on the 97.000 handle again.

EUR/CHF/GBP/JPY

The Euro has fallen victim to the broad Buck revival and failure to rally beyond 1.1200 at the latest attempt, with the single currency shrugging off mixed Eurozone inflation and retail sales data along with confirmation that Spain’s Sanchez secured (just) enough votes to form a government along the way. Eur/Usd subsequently reversed through 1.1150 and the 200 DMA (1.1141), but not far enough to trigger decent option expiry interest at 1.1125 (1.25 bn) at the NY cut. Similarly, the Franc could not sustain 97.000+ territory even though Swiss y/y CPI rose 0.2% from -0.1% previously and vs an anticipated flat reading, while Cable collapsed between 1.3200+/sub-1.3100 parameters on little obvious aside from flow/orders and stop activity, with Eur/Gbp trading inversely. Meanwhile, the Yen derived support from reported supply at 108.50 until overall Dollar strength and improving risk sentiment proved too compelling and Usd/Jpy broke more convincingly through recent peaks to around 108.63.

SEK/NOK 

Choppy trade in Scandinavia as the Swedish Krona extended declines through 10.5500 at one stage, but then recouped the bulk of its losses in contrast to its Norwegian equivalent that also waned with oil.

EM

More power outages from SA’s Eskom and the aforementioned general Greenback rebound that undermined most regional currencies, bar the Cnh (and Cny by proxy), scuppered the Zar, as the Rand swung around sharply from 14.1400 or so to circa 14.3400 before paring back.

DOW

Elsewhere, Boeing and General Dynamics (GD) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense), among others, will compete for each order of the USD 5.1bln Army hybrid contract, GTACS II.
  • Goldman Sachs Group (GS) (Financials/Investment Banking & Brokerage) has announced plans to revamp its financial reporting amid its efforts to increase transparency, WSJ reports, where executives expressed frustration over the share price, which last closed at USD 233.95, and believe it could trade near USD 400.

NASDAQ 100

subject: PRIMER: Non-manufacturing ISM to be released at 1500 GMT/1000 ET; the Street expects a rise
content:
• EXPECTATIONS: The non-manufacturing ISM is seen rising to 54.5 in December (analyst forecast range is between 52.9 and 55.5), from 53.9 in November.
  • OTHER SURVEYS BODE WELL: Analysts note that the Markit gauge of services PMI rose by was revised up on Monday, taking it to 52.8 from the flash 52.2 (NOTE: it has a different composition than the ISM equivalent). The Markit services PMI showed output and new order expansions quicken, but remain at only modest levels. New orders came in at 52.7 vs flash 52.5 and November final 51.6, auguring well for the January data.  Ahead of this week's payrolls report, the employment sub-index rose at the fastest rate since July, Markit said, while inflationary pressures were picking up. The report said the survey results are indicative of GDP rising at a relatively modest annual rate of 1.8% in December. NOTE: desks note that there has been a divergence in the Markit and ISM PMIs, of late. Elsewhere, regional Fed surveys like the Dallas Fed, NY, Richmond, and KC surveys all improved in the month.
  • NON-MANUFACTURING ISM: Focussing on today's non-manufacturing ISM, Nomura's analysts forecast an above-consensus 55.2, arguing that its forecast is consistent with growth roughly at potential, as the non-manufacturing sector continues to weather the industrial slowdown relatively well. "The announced phase one trade deal and news coverage of a possible ramp-up in Chinese purchases of US agricultural products poses some upside risk to the December ISM non-manufacturing index, given the coverage of the agricultural sector," the bank writes.
  • TARIFF IMPACT PRESENTS DOWNSIDE RISKS: Some desks note that, in recent months, the non-manufacturing ISM has been much weaker than implied by its typical relationship with the rate of growth of core retail sales, which Pantheon Macroeconomics assumes is a result of intensifying trade wars in the Spring/Summer. Indeed, that dynamic with core rretail sales has seen Pantheon forecast a fall to 53.0; it argues that any positive follow-through from phase one will be seen in the months ahead, when the dust settles.
  • WATCH THE EMPLOYMENT SUB INDEX: Ahead of this week's employment situation report, watch the employment sib-index. In November, it rose to 55.5, the highest since July, and the third month of improvement. Another rise in December may give credence to the argument that labour demand might not have been as weak as some measures suggested in Q3/Q4 2019, when they signalled cooling labour market momentum.

subject: Fixed and FX latest: debt drifting again, but Buck bid
content: Not a great deal of reaction to the early NA trade data, and not surprising as many market participants will be keeping powder dry for the potentially bigger releases to come at 3 pm (US services PMI and for Canada the IVEY PMI). However, bonds came back under pressure seemingly led by USTs after Bunds and Gilts extended recovery peaks to 172.28 and 131.93 respectively, and prior to the former edging a fresh 172.31 Eurex high. Meanwhile, the Dollar has ticked up across the board, as the DXY inches to 96.885 and Usd/Cad eyes 1.3000 even though both trade gaps were narrower than forecast.

Rabobank thinks that concerns of fiscal largese may be overblown: "We would judge such concerns to be counterbalanced by the fact that the legislative leeway that would be enjoyed by a Socialist-Podemos tie up is likely to be somewhat limited owing to these two parties laying claim to a combined 155 seats (vs. the 176 needed for a majority)."

UK PM Johnson says the Chancellor and himself told the Cabinet that the 11th March Budget will focus on delivering campaign manifestos
analysis_details:
• The Conservatives have pledged to raise capital spending by GBP 20bln per year; there will be less emphasis on the fiscal rules, and the Tories have pledged to re-balance away from the Southeast of England; the manifesto also aims to boost productivity.
  • Analysts say the Budget will be a test for the Tories, specifically, whether manifesto commitments are going to be front loaded in stimulus.
  • The Conservatives have pledged to raise capital spending by GBP 20bln per year; there will be less emphasis on the fiscal rules, and the Tories have pledged to re-balance away from the Southeast of England; the manifesto also aims to boost productivity.
  • Others note that big ticket items will focus on Northern Powerhouse Rail (potentially up to GBP 60bln of additional spending for East-West high speed rail in the North of England).
  • UBS says that, with the Conservative government focused on mainly infrastructure and longer-term projects, it could indicate increased fiscal spending for 2021/22, rather than this year. "This should help support a steeper curve into the end of the year and tough FTA negotiations, pinning front-end yields."
  • UBS adds that, from a political point of view this indicates: 1) that a Cabinet reshuffle should be completed in February prior to the budget; and 2) with that reshuffle in mind, the UK's negotiating position for the EU FTA should be released and negotiations be under way in March.

Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 7th January 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European bourses are firmer as risk-sentiment strengthens on signs of a possible tempering of tensions in the Middle-East
  • USD remains firm ahead of ISM, while the AUD is weighed on post-data and with the ongoing environmental crisis
  • Iran is reportedly assessing 13 scenarios for retaliation against the US and is prepared to "come back to full compliance in the Nuclear deal"
  • US Defense Secretary Esper said the US does not have plans to pull out of Iraq
  • China-US Phase One trade deal is on track and could be signed in the near future, sources told the Global Times
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US ISM-Non-Manufacturing, Factory Orders & International Trade, Canadian Trade Balance. Fed Discount Minutes, supply from US

GEOPOLITICS

Iran is reportedly assessing 13 scenarios for retaliation against the US., Fars; Shamkhani, secretary of the Supreme National Security Council, states the weakest option will turn into a historic nightmare for the US., AJA. (Twitter). Additionally, Iran is prepared to "come back to full compliance in the Nuclear deal", according to a senior Iranian official. (Newswires)

US Defense Secretary Esper said the US does not have plans to pull out of Iraq. This follows reports that US Army told Iraq it is preparing to "move out", according to AFP citing an official letter. The Pentagon could not immediately confirm the authenticity of the letter, but AFP later confirmed the legitimacy. (AFP/Newswires) US Chief of Staff later stated the letter circulating regarding US troops pulling out of Iraq was an unsigned draft and should not have been published. A Pentagon spokeswoman said there is no change in US policy on its troops' presence in Iraq. (Newswires) The Trump administration has begun drafting sanctions against Iraq, according to sources cited by Washington Post. Sources stressed that no decision has been made on whether to implement penalties. One of the officials said the plan was to wait “at least a little while” on the decision in order to see whether Iraqi officials follow through on their threat to push U.S. troops out of the Iraq. (Washington Post)

US Defence Secretary Esper, when asked whether US will strike Iranian cultural sites, said US will follow the laws of armed conflicts. (Newswires) US Chief of Staff noted that according to intel he has seen, IRGC Commander Soleimani was coordinating and preparing simultaneous combat actions against US forces in the region, according to Al-Jazeera. (Al-Jazeera)

US has reportedly barred Iran's Foreign Minister Zarif from entering the US this week to address the UN Security Council about the assassination of General Soleimani, according to diplomatic sources. (Foreign Policy) This was later confirmed by a US official who stated that the US has denied Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif a visa to travel to US for the UN Security Council meeting. (Newswires)

US has issued a warning to ships across Mid-East waterways, regarding the possibility of Iranian action being taken against the US' maritime interests., Associated Press. (Newswires)

Senior IRGC Commander Soleimani's body has arrive at his hometown for burial, according to IRNA. (Newswires) Commander of the Iranian Revolutionary Guard said Iran's response will be strong and humiliating to those who assassinated IRGC Commander Soleimani and "we will avenge the enemy", and added that there is no safe place for Americans in the region, reported via Al-Jazeera. (Twitter) Iranian Parliament has passed a draft bill labelling US military as a terror organisation, via ELINT News. (Twitter)

US Democratic leaders are considering holding votes on two provisions that they had dropped from a compromise defense authorization bill last month amid opposition from the White House and Senate Republicans, according to Al-Monitor. Anti-war activist groups are lobbying Democrats to revive legislation defunding offensive military action against Iran and to repeal the 2002 military authorization that allowed President George. W. Bush to invade Iraq. (Al-Monitor) This would come alongside the anti-war bill that is expected to be voted on later this week which would limit US President Trump's military capability in the Middle East

ASIA-PAC

Asian equities posted gains across the board following a less pronounced but positive handover from Wall Street in which the major indices experienced a modest recovery from the prior session’s losses. ASX 200 (+1.4%) was propped up by its largest-weighed financials as yields recouped from recent downside. Nikkei 225 (+1.6%) retraced some of the prior session’s hefty losses whilst welcoming recent favourable currency moves. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.4%) and Shanghai Comp (+0.7%) conformed to the overall risk appetite - and with the former supported by gains in large-cap financial stocks.

China-US Phase One trade deal is on track and could be signed in the near future, sources told the Global Times. (Twitter)

China Vice Agricultural Minister said China will not increase annual grain import quotas to accommodate higher US farm purchases. This refutes rumours that China may raise or scrap its corn import quota following a phase one trade deal with the US (Newswires/Global Times)

PBoC set USD/CNY reference rate at 6.9690 vs. Exp. 6.9697 (Prev. 6.9718) (Newswires) PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position

Chinese FX Reserves (Monthly)* (Dec) 3.108Trl vs. Exp. 3.103Trl (Prev. 3.096Trl). (Newswires)

Indian Government is likely to cut 2019/20 expenditures by INR 1.5-2.0tln whilst increasing borrowing by INR 300-500bln, according to sources. (Newswires)

UK/EU

No-deal Brexit plans were stood down “with immediate effect” just before Christmas, according to letter seen by Sky News, as UK PM Johnson’s deal is expected to be approved by MPs, but officials worry about cliff edge in December, according to Sky News' Cohen. (Twitter/Sky News)

UK Chancellor Javid has set March 11th as the date for the first budget since the general election. (BBC)

EZ HICP Flash YY (Dec) 1.3% vs. Exp. 1.3% (Prev. 1.0%); HICP-X F&E Flash YY (Dec) 1.4% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 1.4%)

-        HICP-X F,E,A&T Flash YY (Dec) 1.30% vs. Exp. 1.30% (Prev. 1.30%)

-        EZ Retail Sales YY (Nov) 2.2% vs. Exp. 1.3% (Prev. 1.4%, Rev. 1.7%); MM (Nov) 1.0% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. -0.6%, Rev. -0.3%)

EQUITIES

European bourses are firmer this morning, in a turn-around from yesterday’s dismal start to the week (Euro Stoxx 50 +0.5%). Notably, the Dax, which gave up the 13000 handle yesterday, has stayed well-clear of this mark to the downside; with the bourse having printed a cash high of 13266 and a future peak at 13260. Similarly, in contrast to yesterday, and indeed Friday, sectors are all firmly in positive territory with exception of energy names, where yesterday’s outperformers such as Shell (-0.8%) and BP (-0.7%) are under pressure; although, this is to the benefit of airlines such as Air France (+1.5%) and eastJet (+1.4%). Additionally, this downside in the aforementioned energy names is weighing on the FTSE 100 (+0.1%) this morning; with the bourse relatively flat at present. Other notable movers this morning include, Morrisons (+2.5%) after issuing their Christmas sales update and noting that PBT and exceptionals is likely to be within analyst forecasts for FY19/20. At the other end of the Stoxx spectrum are Standard Life Aberdeen and Man Group with both weighed on by broker moves.

FX

AUD/NZD - Already feeling the adverse effects of natural disaster, anecdotal data overnight revealed a sharp decline in the number of Australian jobs advertised on the web and in newspapers to highlight the economic impact of the raging bushfires, with dovish RBA implications. Hence, the Aussie has weakened appreciably across the board, with Aud/Usd slipping through 0.6900 and the 200 DMA (0.6897), while Aud/Nzd has also breached a key chart level at 1.0367 (18 December 2019 low) as the Kiwi contains contagious losses against its US counterpart within 0.6642-80 parameters.

USD - Aside from gleaning traction from the underperformance in Antipodean peers, the Greenback is consolidating off recent lows vs major rivals on a combination of technical and other factors awaiting further developments on the geopolitical front (namely Iran’s response to the US airstrike targeting and killing a top IRGC leader). The DXY has pared declines towards 96.500 and appears more settled in a 96.620-835 range ahead of the upcoming services ISM that could be pivotal for near term Fed policy given the disappointing manufacturing survey and expectations for a firmer headline than previous.

CHF/EUR/CAD/JPY/GBP - As noted above, all weaker against the Buck with the Franc back below 0.9700 and not really inflated by Swiss CPI returning to positive territory in y/y terms, Euro fading ahead of 1.1200 and Loonie losing momentum alongside oil prices in advance of 1.2950 in the run up to Canadian trade data due alongside the US balance for direct comparison. Meanwhile, having met stiff resistance at 108.00 on several occasions of late the Yen is now deriving support from offers said to be capping the headline pair at 108.50, but the Pound has waned markedly after a stop driven rally in Cable on a break of 1.3180 (just above Monday’s peak) to 1.3200+ that pushed Eur/Gbp back under 0.8500 with more gusto and just under 0.8470 before the cross retraced some lost ground.

SEK - Some respite for the Swedish Crown via a less contractionary services PMI, but Eur/Sek is still elevated above the 10.5000 level in contrast to Eur/Nok holding shy of 9.8500.

EM - Although the Dollar has made advances elsewhere, Yuan strength off a marginally firmer PBoC midpoint fix has bucked the general trend, as Usd/Cnh eases back towards mid-December lows not far from 6.9200 and a series of key chart supports closer to 6.9000 amidst reports from the Chinese side alluding to the signing of Phase 1 in the not too distant future.

FIXED INCOME

UK debt remains weak or soft relatively speaking, but well-off worst levels on the back of a solid 2029 DMO Gilt offering that clearly came with a more appealing yield concession for investors to counter some concerns about more issuance to absorb the end of Q1. Indeed, the 10 year benchmark just bounced to a fresh Liffe intraday high of 131.76 to pare net declines on the day to 19 ticks compared to 65 ticks at one stage, while Bunds are hovering just shy of their 172.21 Eurex best (-3 ticks vs -33 ticks) and US Treasuries sit fractionally above parity ahead of a pretty packed pm docket, including the non-manufacturing ISM.

COMMODITIES

The crude complex has dropped into negative territory, with WTI and Brent down by around USD 0.30/bbl at present and approximately USD 1.0/bbl at worst in overnight APAC trade. Newsflow from the Middle-East continues to emerge with the latest pertinent reports noting that Iran is, according to a Fars report, considering 13-scenarios as retaliation against the US. Additionally, a Senior Iranian Official has stated that Iran is prepared to come back to full compliance with the Nuclear Deal. Note, Iran has following the assassination of Soleimani made clear that they are to conduct nuclear related operations on their own accord, disregarding the Nuclear Deal; as such, these remarks potentially indicate a pivot in Iran’s stance against the US and Western powers. However, its worth highlighting that the conditions around their potential return to the deal are not known and previously Iran has indicated sanction relief is a pre-requisite for this type of action. Looking ahead, today sees the funeral of Soleimani and as such participants will now be more actively anticipating/awaiting a response from Iran as the initial mourning period comes to an end. Elsewhere, turning to metals, spot gold is back in positive territory after dipping overnight to a low of USD 1555/oz, prices are now comfortably back above the USD 1560/oz mark; but remain well off yesterday’s multi-year high at USD 1582/oz. Separately, iron ore prices are bolstered following on from China’s main steel making city of Tangshan lifted its level 2 smog alert which was implemented late last week.

Meanwhile, having met stiff resistance at 108.00 on several occasions of late the Yen is now deriving support from offers said to be capping the headline pair at 108.50, but the Pound has waned markedly after a stop driven rally in Cable on a break of 1.3180 (just above Monday’s peak) to 1.3200+ that pushed Eur/Gbp back under 0.8500 with more gusto and just under 0.8470 before the cross retraced some lost ground.

SEK - Some respite for the Swedish Crown via a less contractionary services PMI, but Eur/Sek is still elevated above the 10.5000 level in contrast to Eur/Nok holding shy of 9.8500.

EM - Although the Dollar has made advances elsewhere, Yuan strength off a marginally firmer PBoC midpoint fix has bucked the general trend, as Usd/Cnh eases back towards mid-December lows not far from 6.9200 and a series of key chart supports closer to 6.9000 amidst reports from the Chinese side alluding to the signing of Phase 1 in the not too distant future.

FIXED INCOME

UK debt remains weak or soft relatively speaking, but well-off worst levels on the back of a solid 2029 DMO Gilt offering that clearly came with a more appealing yield concession for investors to counter some concerns about more issuance to absorb the end of Q1. Indeed, the 10 year benchmark just bounced to a fresh Liffe intraday high of 131.76 to pare net declines on the day to 19 ticks compared to 65 ticks at one stage, while Bunds are hovering just shy of their 172.21 Eurex best (-3 ticks vs -33 ticks) and US Treasuries sit fractionally above parity ahead of a pretty packed pm docket, including the non-manufacturing ISM.

COMMODITIES

The crude complex has dropped into negative territory, with WTI and Brent down by around USD 0.30/bbl at present and approximately USD 1.0/bbl at worst in overnight APAC trade. Newsflow from the Middle-East continues to emerge with the latest pertinent reports noting that Iran is, according to a Fars report, considering 13-scenarios as retaliation against the US. Additionally, a Senior Iranian Official has stated that Iran is prepared to come back to full compliance with the Nuclear Deal. Note, Iran has following the assassination of Soleimani made clear that they are to conduct nuclear related operations on their own accord, disregarding the Nuclear Deal; as such, these remarks potentially indicate a pivot in Iran’s stance against the US and Western powers. However, its worth highlighting that the conditions around their potential return to the deal are not known and previously Iran has indicated sanction relief is a pre-requisite for this type of action. Looking ahead, today sees the funeral of Soleimani and as such participants will now be more actively anticipating/awaiting a response from Iran as the initial mourning period comes to an end. Elsewhere, turning to metals, spot gold is back in positive territory after dipping overnight to a low of USD 1555/oz, prices are now comfortably back above the USD 1560/oz mark; but remain well off yesterday’s multi-year high at USD 1582/oz. Separately, iron ore prices are bolstered following on from China’s main steel making city of Tangshan lifted its level 2 smog alert which was implemented late last week.

subject: Nomura quants says trend-following CTAs equity longs look overheated; CTA long USDJPY positions have hit a ceiling as they look to rebuild gold longs
content:
• Nomura's data shows trend-following CTA players have refrained from building risk-averse positions, but there was no pronounced evidence of risk-avoidance behavior in recent trading activity.
  • With that said, Nomura states that CTAs long positions in US equities look somewhat overheated, so a systematic position adjustment could appear likely sometime soon. Nomura estimates that CTAs remain net buyers of S&P 500 futures by only a slim margin.
  • "CTAs swung back and forth during the recent risk-off phase, but in the end they continued to accumulate longs," Nomura writes, "these long positions have now neared the size seen in September 2018 and appear undeniably overheated."
  • The bank estimates that breakeven on existing long positions at around 3,230 for net buying since December 2019, and at 8,760 for NASDAQ 100 futures.
  • With regards to haven currencies (JPY, XAU), Nomura says long positions in USD/JPY appear to have hit a ceiling for now, as CTAs appear to have shifted toward rebuilding their gold futures positions. "However, trend-following algos' purchases of safe-have currencies seem to be merely in line with actual market conditions, and do not look to have rapidly accelerated," the bank says.

subject: PRIMER: Spanish government second investiture vote to take place at 1145 GMT/1245 CET
content:
• Spanish lawmakers will vote to confirm PSOE leader as PM, leading a left-wing minority coalition of PSOE (120 seats) and Podemos (35 seats). The first vote required an absolute majority in the 350-seat lower house, but failed by a margin of 166 to 165.
  • Today's second vote will only require a simple majority, which it is expected to achieve, given that the first vote did not see one Podemos lawmaker participate (Aina Vidal, a Podemos lawmaker, who has cancer, missed Sunday's vote, though will vote today). Additionally, last week PSOE leader Sanchez secure the commitment of Catalan parties to abstain on today's vote, lowering the bar for passage, though raises some risk for the future, since Sanchez in return agreed to open a formal talks on the future of Catalonia if he is confirmed as PM, which will be put to a citizens' vote.
  • Given the left-wing nature of the potential coalition government, desks have focussed on the fiscal implications. Rabobank thinks that concerns of fiscal largese may be overblown: "We would judge such concerns to be counterbalanced by the fact that the legislative leeway that would be enjoyed by a Socialist-Podemos tie up is likely to be somewhat limited owing to these two parties laying claim to a combined 155 seats (vs. the 176 needed for a majority)."

subject: BNP tells clients to buy gold, sell TRY and sell INR to position for Middle East escalation; UBS warns against chasing oil-exporter currencies higher
content:
• BNP Paribas has told clients to buy gold, sell FX oil importer (sell TRY and sell INR), as a hedge against escalating tensions in the Middle East.
  • BNP thinks gold is a better hedge than oil. The Lira specifically is facing geopolitical headwinds, while there are also risks of further monetary easing from the CBRT next week; thus far, reports suggest authorities have been defending the USDTRY 6.00 level to cap losses.
  • For gold, BNP thinks there is scope for the yellow metal to climb to USD 1,650/oz, and also suggests FX that benefits from oil price rises (RUB) could be a secondary play.
  • However, Swiss bank UBS today has warned its clients that, while political tensions are pushing oil prices higher, these type of supply shocks are usually not a good reason to chase oil-exporter currencies higher.
  • UBS says distinguishing between demand vs supply-induced oil moves can matter a great deal with respect to their impact on FX, noting that supply shocks typically have a more negative risk backdrop, which is currently the case.

subject: Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 7th January 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

 

·       US Defense Secretary Esper said the US does not have plans to pull out of Iraq, whilst a Pentagon spokeswoman said there is no change in US policy on its troops' presence in the country

·       Trump administration has begun drafting sanctions against Iraq, according to sources - but plan to wait on the decision to impose penalties

·       China-US Phase One trade deal is on track and could be signed in the near future, sources told the Global Times

·       Asian equities traded higher across the board; Nikkei 225 reversed most of yesterday’s losses

·       In FX, DXY remained within a tight range, USD/JPY tested 108.50 to the upside, USD/CNY briefly dipped below 6.9500

·       Looking ahead, highlights include Swiss CPI, EZ CPI (Flash) & Retail Sales, US ISM-Non-Manufacturing, Factory Orders & International Trade, Canadian Trade Balance. Fed Discount Minutes, supply from UK and US

GEOPOLITICS

US Defense Secretary Esper said the US does not have plans to pull out of Iraq. This follows reports that US Army told Iraq it is preparing to "move out", according to AFP citing an official letter. The Pentagon could not immediately confirm the authenticity of the letter, but AFP later confirmed the legitimacy. (AFP/Newswires) US Chief of Staff later stated the letter circulating regarding US troops pulling out of Iraq was an unsigned draft and should not have been published.  Further reports noted that the US-led coalition is to scale back its operations in Baghdad after an order from Iraq's parliament. (Sky News) However, Pentagon spokeswoman said there is no change in US policy on its troops' presence in Iraq. (Newswires) The Trump administration has begun drafting sanctions against Iraq, according to sources cited by Washington Post. Sources stressed that no decision has been made on whether to implement penalties. One of the officials said the plan was to wait “at least a little while” on the decision in order to see whether Iraqi officials follow through on their threat to push U.S. troops out of the Iraq. (Washington Post)

 

US Defence Secretary Esper, when asked whether US will strike Iranian cultural sites, said US will follow the laws of armed conflicts. (Newswires) US Chief of Staff noted that according to intel he has seen, IRGC Commander Soleimani was coordinating and preparing simultaneous combat actions against US forces in the region, according to Al-Jazeera. (Al-Jazeera)

 

US has reportedly barred Iran's Foreign Minister Zarif from entering the US this week to address the UN Security Council about the assassination of General Soleimani, according to diplomatic sources. (Foreign Policy) This was later confirmed by a US official who stated that the US has denied Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif a visa to travel to US for the UN Security Council meeting. (Newswires)

 

Senior IRGC Commander Soleimani's body has arrive at his hometown for burial, according to IRNA. (Newswires) Commander of the Iranian Revolutionary Guard said Iran's response will be strong and humiliating to those who assassinated IRGC Commander Soleimani and "we will avenge the enemy", and added that there is no safe place for Americans in the region, reported via Al-Jazeera. (Twitter) Iranian Parliament has passed a draft bill labelling US military as a terror organisation, via ELINT News. (Twitter)

 

US military has deployed troops to the Kenya airfield to increase security following the deadly attack by militants of Al Shabaab. Also, US military's Africa command announced it does not believe the attack was linked to Iran. (Newswires)

 

Pentagon is planning to begin deployment of six B-52 bombers to the British territory of Diego Garcia in the Indian Ocean on Monday, CNN reports citing a US official. CNN added the deployment does not signal that operations have been ordered, and that the Pentagon has traditionally deployed long-range bombers and other aircraft as a sign of US force presence and capability. (CNN/Newswires)

 

US Democratic leaders are considering holding votes on two provisions that they had dropped from a compromise defense authorization bill last month amid opposition from the White House and Senate Republicans, according to Al-Monitor. Anti-war activist groups are lobbying Democrats to revive legislation defunding offensive military action against Iran and to repeal the 2002 military authorization that allowed President George. W. Bush to invade Iraq. (Al-Monitor) This would come alongside the anti-war bill that is expected to be voted on later this week which would limit US President Trump's military capability in the Middle East 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equities posted gains across the board following a less pronounced but positive handover from Wall Street in which the major indices experienced a modest recovery from the prior session’s losses. ASX 200 (+1.4%) was propped up by its largest-weighed financials as yields recouped from recent downside. Nikkei 225 (+1.3%) retraced some of the prior session’s hefty losses whilst welcoming recent favourable currency moves. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.7%) and Shanghai Comp (+0.4%) conformed to the overall risk appetite - and with the former supported by gains in large-cap financial stocks.

China-US Phase One trade deal is on track and could be signed in the near future, sources told the Global Times. (Twitter)

China Vice Agricultural Minister said China will not increase annual grain import quotas to accommodate higher US farm purchases. This refutes rumours that China may raise or scrap its corn import quota following a phase one trade deal with the US (Newswires/Global Times)

PBoC set USD/CNY reference rate at 6.9690 vs. Exp. 6.9697 (Prev. 6.9718) (Newswires) PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position

Indian Government is likely to cut 2019/20 expenditures by INR 1.5-2.0tln whilst increasing borrowing by INR 300-500bln, according to sources. (Newswires)

UK/EU

No-deal Brexit plans were stood down “with immediate effect” just before Christmas, according to letter seen by Sky News, as UK PM Johnson’s deal is expected to be approved by MPs, but officials worry about cliff edge in December, according to Sky News' Cohen. (Twitter/Sky News)

UK Chancellor Javid has set March 11th as the date for the first budget since the general election. (BBC)

FX DXY held onto a bulk of the prior day’s losses but remained within a tight 96.68-62 parameter overnight. EUR/USD was contained just under the 1.1200 mark but managed to stay north of its 50 WMA at 1.1174. Meanwhile, GBP/USD drifted higher throughout the session and probed 1.3175 with the pair unreactive to reports that emergency preparations for a no-deal Brexit have been stood down.USD/JPY and JPY-crosses clenched onto recent gains as the overall risk tone kept the pairs afloat, and as the former attempted another test of 108.50 to the upside. Antipodeans traded choppy, albeit within narrow ranges. AUD/USD tested 0.6925 to the downside on multiple occasions but lingered above the figure, whilst its Kiwi counterpart gleaned some support from the AUD/NZD cross losing ground below the psychological 1.0400 level. Finally, CNY saw strength ahead of sources reports that the US-China Phase One deal remains on track - which prompted USD/CNY to test 6.9500 to the downside before briefly dipping below the psychological figure. Note: DXY strengthened to fresh session highs as European participants entered the market and as such, weakness was experienced in G10 pairs in which EUR/USD fell to around 1.1180, GBP/USD tested 1.3150 to the downside and AUD/USD eyed 0.6900 to the downside.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures continued to bleed in overnight trade. Brent front-month contracts dipped below the USD 68/bbl and WTI briefly traded below USD 62.50/bbl vs. recent highs of around USD 70.70/bbl and USD 64.70/bbl respectively. Downside in the complex also coincided with source reports via Washington Post which noted that the Trump administration has begun drafting sanctions against Iraq, but that the plan was to wait and see if Iraq follows through with their threat first rather than immediate penalties. Participants will be on the lookout for any potential Iranian retaliations after IRGC Commander Soleimani’s burial later today, as cautioned by several analysts. Spot gold continued to unwind some of its recent gains, although a sharp move lower of just under USD 10/bbl was seen with little by way of fresh fundamental catalysts to explain the move. Traders cite the downside to stops tripped at prior support around USD 1560/oz. Finally, copper prices were bolstered by the overall risk-sentiment but stopped short of resistance at USD 2.79/lb.

 

OPEC+ said it will respond to any oil emergency from the crisis in Iran, however spare capacity is tight, according to Platts Oil. (Platts)

US 

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (H20) SETTLES 4+ TICKS LOWER AT 129-08. The Treasury complex saw some profit-taking after gains seen at the start of the year, and amid a lack of fresh developments on the US/Iran front; the shape of the curve was little changed, while nominal yields inched up slightly. Analysts chewed the fat over the Iran situation, and there seems to be a consensus that from the oil market's perspective, the status quo is manageable (although much of that will depend on the next moves from stakeholders). Decent services PMI data out of major markets on Monday also helped, and the upward revision to the US Markit services PMI raises hopes of a decent ISM services print on Tuesday. Additionally, the corporate supply slate is heavy, with expectations of around USD 30bln of corporate dollar supply on tap for this week, while some have suggested that it might be as high as USD 40bln.

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asian equities rebound following a mild recovery on Wall Street
content:
Asian equities are posting gains across the board following a less pronounced but positive handover from Wall Street in which in the major bourses experienced a modest recovery from the prior session’s losses. ASX 200 (+0.9%) is propped up by its largest-weighed financials as yields recouped from recent downside. Nikkei 225 (+0.8%) is retracing some of the prior session’s hefty losses whilst welcoming recent favourable currency moves. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.7%) and Shanghai Comp (+0.4%) conform to the overall risk appetite - and with the former supported by gains in large-cap financial stocks.

In FX markets, DXY hold onto a bulk of the prior day’s losses but remained within a tight 96.67-62 parameter. EUR/USD trades choppy just under the 1.1200 mark but manages to stay north of its 50 WMA at 1.1174. Meanwhile, GBP/USD drifts higher throughout the session and probed 1.3175 with the pair unreactive to reports that emergency preparations for a no-deal Brexit have been stood down as UK PM Johnson’s deal is almost certain to make its passage through parliament. That said, officials remain concerned regarding a cliff-edge Brexit, according to Sky News’ Cohen. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses clench onto recent gains as the overall risk tone kept the pairs afloat, with the former re-eyeing 108.50 to the upside. Finally, Antipodeans trade choppy, albeit within narrow ranges. AUD/USD tested 0.6925 to the downside on multiple occasions but lingers above the figure.
